Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Multifunctional materials for ultrasound diagnosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project targets multifunctional meta-materials having acoustic impedance equal to tissue and optimized for solid-state tactile sensing. Optimized multifunctional performance of these newly developed meta-materials includes enhanced mechanical, acoustic and self-sensing response. The innovation of the proposed approach is in building two hierarchical levels of the material microstructure: (1) a meta-structured layer which is photo-lithographically patterned with specified features and (2) meta-structural elements which are comprised of aligned chains of nano-inclusions. The proposed manufacturing approach can be applied to a wide range of polymeric systems. However, this project targets materials which are suitable for biomedical applications and are compatible with clean-room processing. Critical manufacturing steps which will be developed and verified during the proposed Phase I research efforts include mixing nano-inclusions in polymeric photoresist, spinning polymer layers, aligning inclusions by electric field, and photolithographically defining meta-structures. The acoustic, mechanical and electro-active properties of the resulting materials will be experimentally verified.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be the fostering of novel approaches in ultrasound screening and medical diagnosis. The intended commercial application of the proposed materials is for acoustically transparent sensing layers in tactile sensing arrays, where this material has the potential to operate in front of an ultrasound transducer without adversely affecting imaging performance. A primary near-term impact of these new tactile sensing technologies will be the availability of contact pressure feedback signals during the ultrasound imaging procedure. Such tactile feedback would allow the operator to correct his/her mistakes and enable telemedicine through operation of diagnosis equipment by inexperienced users or remotely. This will improve the accuracy and broaden the utility of ultrasound as a diagnostic tool. Combining ultrasound imaging and tactile sensing also has the potential to revolutionize biopsy-free screening of breast and prostate cancers, reducing discomfort to patients and lowering the overall cost of the medical screening. Finally, an overall increase in the efficiency of ultrasound probes will enable highly efficient and portable ultrasound instruments. This would improve medical screening worldwide, especially in low-income areas, in small hospitals, and in point-of-care settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-SBIR Phase I research project was focused on developing multifunctional meta-materials having desired mechanical, acoustic, and self-sensing properties. The novelty of our proposed approach was building two hierarchical levels of the material's microstructure: (1) a photo-lithographically patterned meta-structure with features much smaller than the acoustic wavelength and (2) meta-structural elements formed from a composite containing aligned chains of nano-inclusions. In addition, this technology for material manufacture is compatible with clean-room processing and suitable for biomedical applications. During Phase I, CoMMET, LLC accomplished the project goals and tasks. This report presents micro-images of the desired meta-elements and describes the steps for manufacturing such elements. Briefly, the main manufacturing steps are: (1) uniformly dispersing nano-inclusions in the desired matrix material to form a suspension, (2) spin-coating a layer of that suspension on the substrate, (3) curing the suspension in an electric field to obtain aligned structure of inclusions, (4) spin-coating a layer of photo-definable material, such as SU-8 photoresist, and patterning a mask corresponding to the desired structure, (5) developing and hard baking SU-8 pattern, and (6) utilizing that pattern as a mask for plasma-etching the anisotropic layer in the meta-structure. This Phase I final report presents a detailed description of technological steps, describes the challenges we overcame during Phase I, and outlines future paths that can be pursued with other materials. The process we created in Phase I included the following:

Anisotropic material substrates with aligned inclusions are created by applying an electric field during the curing process. The magnitude and frequency of the electric field, and the curing regimes, are determined based on preliminary experimental testing.

SU-8 top layer is utilizes for forming a plasma-etching mask. Spinning the desired thickness of the layer may need more refinements to adjust the correct spinning and soft-baking conditions.

Photolithographically pattern SU-8 photoresist masks by UV exposure through a photo-mask, develop and hard-bake the resultant structure.

Final meta-structure is obtained by plasma-etching the designed pattern through the SU-8 mask.

Most experiments used Araldite resin as the matrix material, graphite or silicone oxide nano- particles as the inclusions, and SU-8 as the photoresist. A similar approach could be applied to other materials, once the appropriate parameters for the processes have been established. This includes a regimen of electric field exposure to create an anisotropic structure in the desired matrix material, a selection of suitable material for photo-definable masks and layer thickness, setting reacting plasma gases and reacting time.

This NSF-SBIR funding is essential for CoMMET to successfully bridge the “valley of death” between academic research and commercialization. For example, the current research activity supports an NIH R01 project “Quantitative Mechanical Imaging for Improving Breast Ultrasound Diagnosis.” CoMMET’s core technologies are needed to develop a tactile pressure array that will operate directly in front of an ultrasound probe. More broadly we would like to develop a new ultrasound diagnostic approach based on reconstructing the elastic modulus of different types of tissue. These capabilities will eventually lead to biopsy-free cancer screening and diagnosis. This initial project, tactile pressure arrays for medical applications, is considered as closest to successful commercialization and our Commercial Plan and technical research plans in Phase I and Phase II of this NSF-SBIR are built around this ap...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This NSF-SBIR Phase I research project was focused on developing multifunctional meta-materials having desired mechanical, acoustic, and self-sensing properties. The novelty of our proposed approach was building two hierarchical levels of the material's microstructure: (1) a photo-lithographically patterned meta-structure with features much smaller than the acoustic wavelength and (2) meta-structural elements formed from a composite containing aligned chains of nano-inclusions. In addition, this technology for material manufacture is compatible with clean-room processing and suitable for biomedical applications. During Phase I, CoMMET, LLC accomplished the project goals and tasks. This report presents micro-images of the desired meta-elements and describes the steps for manufacturing such elements. Briefly, the main manufacturing steps are: (1) uniformly dispersing nano-inclusions in the desired matrix material to form a suspension, (2) spin-coating a layer of that suspension on the substrate, (3) curing the suspension in an electric field to obtain aligned structure of inclusions, (4) spin-coating a layer of photo-definable material, such as SU-8 photoresist, and patterning a mask corresponding to the desired structure, (5) developing and hard baking SU-8 pattern, and (6) utilizing that pattern as a mask for plasma-etching the anisotropic layer in the meta-structure. This Phase I final report presents a detailed description of technological steps, describes the challenges we overcame during Phase I, and outlines future paths that can be pursued with other materials. The process we created in Phase I included the following: Anisotropic material substrates with aligned inclusions are created by applying an electric field during the curing process. The magnitude and frequency of the electric field, and the curing regimes, are determined based on preliminary experimental testing. SU-8 top layer is utilizes for forming a plasma-etching mask. Spinning the desired thickness of the layer may need more refinements to adjust the correct spinning and soft-baking conditions. Photolithographically pattern SU-8 photoresist masks by UV exposure through a photo-mask, develop and hard-bake the resultant structure. Final meta-structure is obtained by plasma-etching the designed pattern through the SU-8 mask. Most experiments used Araldite resin as the matrix material, graphite or silicone oxide nano- particles as the inclusions, and SU-8 as the photoresist. A similar approach could be applied to other materials, once the appropriate parameters for the processes have been established. This includes a regimen of electric field exposure to create an anisotropic structure in the desired matrix material, a selection of suitable material for photo-definable masks and layer thickness, setting reacting plasma gases and reacting time. This NSF-SBIR funding is essential for CoMMET to successfully bridge the "valley of death" between academic research and commercialization. For example, the current research activity supports an NIH R01 project "Quantitative Mechanical Imaging for Improving Breast Ultrasound Diagnosis." CoMMETÃ†s core technologies are needed to develop a tactile pressure array that will operate directly in front of an ultrasound probe. More broadly we would like to develop a new ultrasound diagnostic approach based on reconstructing the elastic modulus of different types of tissue. These capabilities will eventually lead to biopsy-free cancer screening and diagnosis. This initial project, tactile pressure arrays for medical applications, is considered as closest to successful commercialization and our Commercial Plan and technical research plans in Phase I and Phase II of this NSF-SBIR are built around this application.
